_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary: 



This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for Valero Renewable Fuels Company, LLC d.b.a. Valero Albion Plant dry mill ethanol production facility located in Albion, NE.  This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR 68) and Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act.  The Valero Albion Plant ethanol facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated toxic substance, and natural gasoline, a regulated flammable mixture, above the threshold quantities.  This RMP submittal is for the required RMP five year update.



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

Valero Albion Plant is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public.  Management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  The design and construction of the facility has incorporated physical and operational safeguards to prevent accidental releases.  Through the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of the equipment, and the training of our personnel, Valero Albion Plant has minimized the hazard to human health and the environment from fires, explosions, or any unplanned sudden or non-sudden release of hazardous materials.  



In the event that a release does occur, the facility's emergency response actions are described in its Facility Repsonse Plan (FRP) and/or Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) Plan.  These plans includeprocedures to coordinate response actions with local emergency response personnel (i.e., law enforcement, fire, and rescue departments, emergency medical services, hospital and government personnel, etc.) as well as any potentially affect

ed neighbors.  In addition, they are used to familiarize local emergency response personnel with the types of material handled and internal emergency response procedures.



2.    Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The Valero Albion Plant facility is a 110 million gallon per year corn-based dry-mill denatured ethanol fuel production plant.  Ethanol is produced through the conversion of corn starch to sugars and then conversion of the sugars to ethanol (i.e., grain alcohol) through a continuous fermentation and distillation process. 



Regulated substances stored at the facility include anhydrous ammonia, which is used for pH control and as a nutrient in the fermentation process, and natural gasoline, which is used as a denaturant in the ethanol fuel product.



3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Valero Albion Plant has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by EPA, process safety management (PSM) requirements from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations.  The facility complies with PSM for the management of ethanol and ammonia.



Employee Participation

Valero Albion Plant has developed an employee participation program.  All process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, and action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plans, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel at any time.



Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information

The facility utilizes a HazOp methodology for Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  The PHA identified the following potential major hazards:  toxic release, fire, explosion, over-pressurization, corrosion, over-filling and equipment failure.  The facility utilizes process controls such as vents, re

lief valves, check valves, manual shutoffs, automatic shutoffs, alarms and procedures, grounding equipment, and excessive flow devices to prevent or limit releases.  



Valero Albion Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the facility.  Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  The facility also maintains technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, piping and instrument drawings.



Operating Procedures and Training

Valero Albion Plant maintains written procedures that address all modes of process operations, including normal operations, manual operation, regeneration, and emergency shutdown. The facility has developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in facility operations.  



Contractors

The contractor safety procedures establish minimum guidelines and activities in order to assure that the contractor's employees follow safe work practices and procedures.  The procedure includes a contractor screening process and hazard awareness, safety and emergency procedures training.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

Valero Albion Plant conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) for any new facility or facility modification that requires a significant change in the process safety information, based on a specific set of criteria.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.



Mechanical Integrity

The facility's mechanical integrity program includes written procedures, training, and regular inspections and equipment testing procedures

to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems, and controls in a safe operating condition.  



Management of Change

The facility's management of change (MOC) program reviews all proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials, and design conditions prior to implementation of the change.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change.  



Incident Investigation

Valero Albion Plant has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a release of a regulated substance.  The procedures establish the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases.  Investigations will be undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent a similar release in the future.



Compliance Audits

The facility will conduct audits of the provisions of RMP to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed.  The audit will include a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel.



4.      Accident History

The facility has not had any accidents reportable under RMP.  This RMP submittal is for the required RMP five year update.. 



5.    Emergency Response Program

Valero Albion Plant maintains a written emergency response program in its FRP and SPCC plans.  The purpose of these plansis to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The plans address aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and

accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, Valero Albion Plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  We work with the local fire department and emergency responders to ensure the proper execution of our plan.  The emergency response program will be updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes. 



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Valero Albion Plant facility has been designed and constructed to meet existing construction and process safety requirements.  Valero Albion Plant will continue to evaluate and implement changes as necessary to improve safety at the facility.  At the time of this RMP submission, there are no immediate changes planned to improve safety.
